Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: From genotype to fluxome to a comprehensive kinetic model of Escherichia coli

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Elucidating and quantifying the complexities of biological systems is of fundamental and practical interest to synthetic biologists and metabolic engineers. A useful approach to unraveling biological complexity is to observe the biological system under perturbed conditions, for example, by removing key cellular components such as genes. In this study, responses to gene knockouts in the model microorganism Escherichia coli will be investigated. By systematically measuring cellular responses to the removal of specific genes in central carbon metabolism a high-quality data set will be generated that will then be used to construct a predictive kinetic model. In addition to having significant value in advancing fundamental biological sciences, this model will provide a valuable new toolkit for industrial biotechnology. Additionally, this model will form the basis for the development of new and enhanced educational tools that will introduce high-school and college students to the biological systems at an early age.

Developing a predictive kinetic model of cellular metabolism has been the desire of the scientific community for many decades. However, limitations in experimental approaches for measuring precise metabolic fluxes and the daunting task of estimating a large number of kinetic parameters in models of cellular metabolism have prevented its realization. In recent years, a number of major breakthroughs have been achieved that allow, for the first time, this long-standing task to be accomplished successfully. First, new experimental approached based on parallel 13C-labeling experiments have greatly improved the precision and accuracy of flux measurements. Second, the ensemble kinetic modeling approach was developed and validated for biological systems, which allows systematic construction of comprehensive kinetic models of cellular metabolism while limiting problems of parameter identifiability that have been a major concern in the past and have limited previous modeling approaches. In this project, metabolic flux redistribution in response to gene knockouts will be comprehensively assessed for a large number of E. coli knockout strains, both single gene and double knockouts, enabling the development of a comprehensive kinetic model of central metabolism. The proposed work will add to the scientific knowledge by: (1) generating extensive high-quality experimental data on metabolic fluxes for a large number of E. coli mutant strains using state-of-the-art 13C-flux analysis methods; (2) providing a comprehensive kinetic model of cellular metabolism for E. coli, an important academic and industrial microbe; (3) developing and implementing best practices, standards, procedures and tools for performing, documenting and sharing of 13C-flux analysis results and kinetic models; (4) building a framework to integrate multiple omics data sets within the ensemble modeling framework; (5) generating new knowledge and insights about the regulation of E. coli metabolism under glucose-rich and glucose-limited conditions.

This award was co-funded by the Systems and Synthetic Biology (SSB) program in the Molecular and Cellular Biosciences (MCB) Division in the Biological Sciences Directorate and the Biotechnology and Biochemical Engineering (BBE) program of the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems (CBET) in the Engineering Directorate.

Project Outcomes Report ? NSF Award# 1615646

Project Title: Collaborative Research: From genotype to fluxome to a comprehensive kinetic model of Escherichia coli

Recipient Organization: Pennsylvania State University, University Park

Project/Grant Period: 08/15/2016 ? 07/31/21
PI: Costas D. Maranas

 

Kinetic models of metabolism can capture the systems-level metabolic response to changes in metabolite concentration and enzyme level and describe aspects of the metabolic phenotype outside of the scope of traditional stoichiometric models. However, their widespread adoption and use has been limited because the data needed for parameterizing large-scale kinetic models is scarce, computational expense for parameterization is high, substrate-level regulatory networks tend to be poorly defined for non-model organisms, and unless scaled to the genome scale, many systemic effects captured by stoichiometric models are missed. With these challenges in mind, this project has sought to develop tools and workflows to accelerate the development of kinetic models of metabolism with genome-wide coverage so that they may be readily used to generate non-intuitive design strategies for bioproduction.

To this end, we have developed K-FIT, a gradient-based kinetic parameterization algorithm which offers accelerated parameterization and superior fitness to training data over metaheuristic parameterization methods. In addition to offering gradient-directed traversal of the parameters space, K-FIT exploits the mathematical properties of the elementary decomposition kinetic formalism to bypass the time-consuming evaluation of the system of ordinary differential equations describing change in metabolite and enzyme complex concentration with respect to time. Network scalability to the near-genome scale has been demonstrated in Escherichia coli with the construction of k-ecoli307, containing 307 reactions, 258 metabolites, and 69 substrate-level inhibitions. We have made K-FIT available with examples at our group?s GitHub page (https://github.com/maranasgroup/K-FIT).

We have further coupled K-FIT kinetic parameterization with 13C-metabolic flux analysis (13C-MFA), a computational tool which infers an intracellular metabolic flux distribution from stable isotopic labeling data, to formalize a workflow and identify best practices for parameterizing kinetic models of metabolism from fluxomics data. Using isotopic labeling data generated by our experimental collaborators, we parameterize a kinetic model of E. coli core metabolism (i.e. k-ecoli74), and demonstrate the need for network congruence between flux elucidation and kinetic parameterization to ensure model accuracy. We further use cross-validation analysis to demonstrate the need for mutant training datasets with unique flux redirection from the wild-type strain to maximize predictive capability. We demonstrate how local sensitivity analysis can be used to identify metabolic control points, and in calculating parameter standard deviations identify 26 of 55 substrate-level inhibitions which play an active role in controlling metabolic flux in E. coli central carbon metabolism. Our 13C-MFA tools are available at our groups GitHub page (https://github.com/maranasgroup/SteadyState-MFA).

To demonstrate applicability in non-model organisms, we extend our parameterization pipeline to construct a core kinetic model of Clostridium thermocellum (i.e. k-ctherm138) from heterogeneous fluxomics and fermentation yield datasets. In performing 13C-MFA to generate a wild-type flux distribution needed for kinetic parameterization, we identify the mercaptopyruvate pathway as a source of L-serine synthesis. We deploy k-ctherm138 to uncover the substrate-level regulatory limitations to ethanol yield and titer. Because the C. thermocellum substrate-level regulatory network is not well-characterized, we develop an enzyme-ligand docking workflow for identifying previously undiscovered competitive inhibitions. We use our docking workflow together with k-ctherm138 to identify 6 glycolytic substrate-level inhibitions supported by both kinetic formalism and structural-energetic analysis. The methods developed in this project will serve as a means for accelerating kinetic parameterization and expanding the substrate-level regulatory networks (and thus model fidelity) of large-scale kinetic models for non-model organisms of industrial importance.
